"The General inc Chief Of the Republican
Army has the pleasure to inform His lIx-
cellency the Minister of War, that, after
two partial skirmishes in the former OF
which, on the 18th instant, the division OF
Nentus Manuel was attacked and beaten by
Colonel Lavalle, and on the 10Th by Gen.
Mansilla; yesterday. tire Goth, the Bcpubli
can army encountered the Imperial army on
the camp Of ltu2aingo The force of the
latter amounted to $500 men OF artillery
and cavalry. They fought for SIX hours
with skin ard energy, bur Welded at last to
the efforts OF or heroes, their cavalry being
completely routed and dispersed abandoning
the field Of battle, and leaving on It more
than 1920 dead bodies, among them that of
Marshal Abreu, 10 pieces Of artillery, all
their ammunition and baggage, with con
siderable number Of prisoners and arms.
The ,oss of the army ofthe Republic does
not exceed AGO men between killed and
wounded: among the former is to be regret
ted Col. bfand2en, who fell on the first charge
at the front of his regiment


"lt IS impossible at present 70 give a de
tail OF the events of the Goth: the General
in-Chief VIII transmit 1t very shortly. In the
meantime Lieutenant Coionel Aguirre, the
bearer OF this despatch, will inform your llx
cellencv OF them, and viii also present twc
standards which are the trophies pf the vic.
tory.


"Ihe advantages and consequences Of the
victory are immense. The General in
Chiet pursues the enemy to avail himself o
them; and, in the name of the army, he con
graduates both the Government and the Ma
tion. he General has the satisfaction e
assure the Minister of War, that every ind
vidnal OF the army has contributed in III,
most distinguished manner, to the happ,
result OF the battle of the Goth. The Under
signed hopes it will be communicated to Hi
Excellency the President, whom he salute
with his most distinguished respect.


"CARLOS DE ALVEAR.


"1o II. Is. the Minister of IHur."

The family of Canning. from which the
present eminent and justly popular Prime
Minister springs, is of great antiquity.


The head the family was Roman Cath
oic gentleman. Francis Canning Esq, Of
Foxcote, in Warwick shire, the twelfth pos
SCISSOR of that estate, in lincal male descent
from Thomas Canning Esq. who, in the
reign of Henry VI, married Agnes, sole
heiress of lie Marshal, of Foxcotc, seated
there, from the time of Edward l.


The branch from which the premier de-
rives his origin was founded by George Can
ming, younger son of Richard Canning, of
Foxcote, who settled in Ireland. and obtain
ed grant Of the manor of Garvah. in the
county of Londonderry, from Queen Eliza
beth. From him descended Stratford Can
ning, Esq the fifth possessor of the Garvah
estate, who derived his Christian name from
the surname Of his mothcr's family, the
Stratfords, Earls of Aidborough; his eldest
son, George Canning, died in his fathers
lifetime leaving an only son, the Right Hon
orabie George Canning, who, though repre-
sentative OF tic elder branch OF the Garvah
family, was passed by in the will of his grand
father. who left the estate TO his second soi
Paul Canning, ESQ whose only son, George
Canning was created Baron GArvah in 1878.


The premier, however, succeeded to
small estate in the county of Kilkenny, OF
about $500 per annum, either by bequest,
or in consequence of the entail net being
broken. On this slender beginning he has
finally achieved his present proud pre- emi-
nence.


(Fr9m the London Eree Press.

near London, in 177l. His paterpal ances-

| Under these circumstances he cane w'tn
his lady to London, and determining to study
the law, entered himself of the Middle en- :
pie. lie died poor, on the lith Of .lprl''
l77l, . few davs ufter the birth Of his son
George, and was Inferred in the new hnrii
ground OF St. Marylebone, where his sorl''
with the following inscription, was placed ~
his widow -


Thy virtue and my wo, no words can tel,
! Therefore, a little while, my George, sareweili


For faith and love ike ours, Heaven has IN stofS
Its last best gift--to meet and part no more


His infant son, the subject Of this remor'
was placed with maternal uncle, "A F&s'ec.-
able wine merchant in the city, who discos
ering strong marks of genius, at very ear. ,,..
ly age, sent him to Eton, where he speeuNJ
distinguished himself, and in 1888, oeca'A-
one of the senior scholars.

The last New Harmony Gazette contains
the address of Robert Owen, the proprietor
of that community, previous to his leaving
.he place for Europe. He enumerates the
difficulties he has experienced in carrying
his project into effect, and the causes Of his
failure. lie has sold a part, and leased out
the remainder of his property at New Har-
mony to communities on a small scale, and
thinks that on this plan his hopes Of success
will in some measure be realized. He re-
commends to those he leaves behind him, in
dustry, economy, perseverance and kindness,
to one another, and hopes to meet them a.
gain under more favorable auspices.

lnglancing over the files of Buenos Ayrcs
papers alluded to in our last, we have found
few interesting articles relating to that
portion OF our continent, which we give be-
low.


Another revolutionary movement took
place at Santiago, in Chill, short time since.
in an attempt of the military, headed by
that restless and dangerous man CAMPING,
to dissolve the sitting Of the Sovereign Con
gress and to abolish the Eatanco. For this
purpose the troops were formed in front of
the Congress Hall, and some muskets were
discharged, but without effect, and the Con
gress merely suspended its sitting. in the
meanwhile, CAMPING took possession OF the
Government House, imprisoned the Secreta-
ry of Foreign Relations and the Chief Of the
E.stanco, and proclaimed himself President
of the Republic. Negotiations then COM
mcncca between him and the Congress, but
before coming to any conclusion, the troops
deserted him, and he and his principal ad-
herents were thrown into prison. 1t is thus
that the rcpose of Chill is continually dis
turbed by the different factions that alter
nately distract her Councils, and hold in
check any considerable improvement in her
institutions.


he deputies who were sent by the gov
ernment OF Buenos Ayres to present the
constitution to the dissident provinces, have


been unsuccessful in their mission; and
/ with the exception OF one or two, had re.

A letter has been received from Captain
Worrcl. of the Tontine, the first vessel des.
patched from Philadelphia with provisions
for the Greeks, announcing his safe arrival
at Gibraltar on the 21st of April, after pas
sage OF "a days. lie says, II am sorry to
say there are none of our squadron here at
present, all being up the Mediterranean; we
are, therefore, unable to obtain any informa-
ton from that quarter. Should we be so
fortunate as to meet either of them, it is the
general impression that they will give US
convoy" Capt. w. proceeded on his voy-
| age Oh the esd.

We understand that thc Corporation of
this Borough have purchased the Mill ad-
Joining the Brandywinc bridge, Of Mr.. John
Cummins, and in the course of the ensuing
Summer it viii be used to raise the water
from the Brandywine Greek for tie use Of
this town.


Our citizens have long felt the want Of
a suiicIency Of water to answer ordinary
purposes, and should fire at any time have
occurred, the destruction of properly would
have been very great, The water will be
raised to the basin already constructed, and
distributed through iron pipes.

The Postmaster General Of the United
States, left Washington on Friday. on Wis
it to his domcile in the State of Ohio, being
the first visit he has made thither since his
appointment TO office. four or five years ago.
He is expected to be absent for five or six
weeks.

Jesclh q. Ro79iaad, has been appointed
by the Governor Of this State, y be Judge
Il the Supreme Conrt.

LETTER ~.

state of distraction, and to render the prosPee'
widely unlike those scenes OF quietude, wnch
soothe and soften the mind, and bid It reject
with composure. Here we were above all living
beings. the sole inhabitants ofa region far above
the lofty fight Of the eagle, where the foot OF
the chamois never ventures, and where man mas
seldom BEEN


We stood amidst the frowns Of savage Nature,
almost insensble to every object beneath' ana
silently contemplating the coudIess heaSe"s'
pure and bright as the I'm, ied wastes OF s,oW
around and beneath. liere all worldly passions
cease; mans thoughts occupy themselves III
more worthy train of reflection; he fofge's inc
Injustice of his enemies ms sou' raises 'seii 70
heaven. as its nearest point, and reioices to feel
it..lf nearer the abode of truth. "Le vra nous
Went du ciel, l'erreur Went dc la terre." When
we meet we viii enlarge upon the subject, IN ihe
mean time will briefly state our mode OF descent
an operation very different from that pursued in
ascending.
On reaching the edge of the decHyity which
led to the Petlts Mulets, Contet told me that
would not be safe to walk down, and on inquiry
itound the usual practice was to seat yol.rsel on
the ice between two guides, and thus slie GOWN
IN few minutes the distance which had cost us
an hour and half to ascend lsubmiited to the
plan suggested to me; and though the operation
1 somewhat hazardous, the agility OF the guides
in regulating the velocity by means OF thelr
poles, seems to remove all danger. In descend
ing this first slope by this new method, cast
my ewes once or twice over the precipice TO our
right hand, ana had Just one moment to THINK,
that if by an Inflated turn, VIC had directed our
course that way, it appeared that We shoulI
most unexpectedly have paid visit to the good
monks Of St. Bernard. When ut Les Pet'ts NiIl-
lets, begged Coutet to stop q few minutes tha'
l might once more look up at the hoary summit
Of Mont Blanc; and having rested = short time,
and gathered few fragments OF granite from
sls, the highest bare point, we continued our
line of march.


The Grand Plateau, whose heightened PLAIN
extends nearly league and halt, IS NOT very
comforting to traveller ready to sink under an
accumulation of fatigue and exhaustion { ha0
,rcely eaten any food during the day a'ew %
Coutets figs and raisins had satisfied me- aha 4
mong the guides, only halt OF a three pound
loaf had been devoured and two small CHICKENS
which certainly on any other accustomed expc-
tlitions would scarcely have sutfced for one;
and our consumption OF wine did not TINS day
amount to three bottles. Having crossed the
Grand Plateau, which required an hour and q
half to cross it owing to the deep snow, We STOOD
for few minutes debating what means would
be the most secure to descend what cndeavor-
ed to describe to you before a3 the great Mon
tees. To slide seemed impractlcabe llis
slope had been warmed by the sun IN inc u o.
day. when We passed it; but now, owing to the
shade and cold winds, it had again frozen, and
was become exceeding dangerous, Something
was to be done; for to remain there tii night,
destitute Of food, firing and clothes, was not We
~ desirable. We, therefore, began 10 WALK
with very careful and deliberate step, placing
our feet in the track we had made IN the morn
ing. We slowly crawled downward tor somt
time, using every precaution not to slipi Tor lho
we were attached to each other by ropes stil
the fall of one might endanger others and TO th'
base of the Montees was about twice a.iiigh a
the dome of St. Paus Cathedral. had not de
.cended more than one hundred, or one hundrct
and ffty feet, before fell and Instantly the snov
began to roll with me, nor could stop mysel
Until the ropes were extended to their full length
Coutet cried out-"Ne bongez pas, Monsieur
ne faites pas lie moindre movement 1t reI'iI
e some little selfcommand to obey his order.
but remained perfectly quiet, though not YER
composed, until he gave me directions to enlc.
yor to press my heels into the snow, and thu
raise myself little, while the two guides VIII
held the ropes should by degrees pull me up I
the path from whence had fallen, In trying t
press nv feet forcblv into the snow, they cam
IN contact with the ice, and slipped, SO that M
efforts were quite useless However by the Y
most exertion in my power, and the force OF IN
guides was pulled up, but required some i
tie time to recover my senses; for swinging a
most in the air, Immediately over great


depth, with some doubt of the result Of the m
nnuvre was for the moment a little nervous.


Two orthree other trining slips brought ust Il
small Plateau over which we walked as rapid
as fatigue would allow us, When at its extrcr
ity, we had the smaller Montees to descend; b
as this was much less steep, and only about hs
the height of the other, we all sat down, NJ
were very soon comfortably landed at its b Sc
never enioyed the pleasure of descending Il
Montagnes Cusses, which were formerly fashio
able near Paris; but apprehend our slides WEI
very similar to them.-We now witnessed tg
or three grand avalanches; but happily for II
they took an oblique direction, and we remainc
stationary to observe the fall The avalanche
which fall directly from the mountain tops, thu
der down with deafening rear; but those whit
merely slip down the snowy sleeps, cause lit
noise, but raise cloud Of white dust, whit
marks their progress, and produces a beautif
effect. When we reached the edge of the G.
cier de Tacconia about six O'Clock, it was GO
ting dusk; and we had to cross deep al
frghtful chasn in order to save very considt


able circuit. This passage was only practicah


bylaying four or FIVE poles in horizontal po


lion, and thus making bridge, having ropes


hxed to each person. To descend the crew


was out Of the question, for It was very dee
and contained watcr and ice appa emily not s.


fciently frozen TO support our weight I


poles were laid, but not in very secure ,nanr


and the leading guides, throwing their En,


sacks over before them, in order to be light

disposition was made by procuring b,r,.,
Of tar, to which they set fire in The sei a;a,
near the college buildings, and danced rona. sus
it yelling like savages. After this ceren0" uu
ny, which seems to have been intended aa
kind OF declaration Of war, they proceea.,
to actual hostilities A quantity of pow5.a
was placed under the tutors chair w;.s
train leading to il, and while he was h.arina
their lessons, the train was set ON fir. Ing .n
the gentleman suddenly enveloped in Aana
and smoke. fed for his fe.-Soon after ,he
chapel bell, which had so long annoyed thss.
young worthless by its importunate summons
to prayers and recitations, was taken down
and it is supposed thrown into the river 4
variety Of other pranks were PLAYED bu, -,
CLIENT inquiries being set on foot to discove,
the ring leaders in these disturbances tbrsa
of them have been sent away. and the re-
mainder are beginning to be satisfied.


The annual examination of the Cadets =.
West Point, will take place next week c.,
Andrew M. Provost, of PHILADELPHIA. and
Joseph Ritncr, Esq. of Washington county
the speaker of the House of Representatives
of Pennsylvania, will constitute, under tbr
invitation of the Secretary of War, a part Of
the board OF yisiters and examiners.


On Monday last, in New-York, four bows
between the ages of nine and twelve years
were committed to Biidewell, on charge
of robbing Sabbath School. For the last
two months, they had been in the habit OF
watching opportunities during the absenc.
OF the sections OF two churches. in the vicin.
'ty of Bowery and Spring street, to pocke
the collections taken up during service.

full articles.headline:
From NE argentine .Ae7ys.
VIVA LA PATRIAi
full articles.article:
'Viead QumtcrSm march, FEB. 81, 1897.


"The General inc Chief Of the Republican
Army has the pleasure to inform His lIx-
cellency the Minister of War, that, after
two partial skirmishes in the former OF
which, on the 18th instant, the division OF
Nentus Manuel was attacked and beaten by
Colonel Lavalle, and on the 10Th by Gen.
Mansilla; yesterday. tire Goth, the Bcpubli
can army encountered the Imperial army on
the camp Of ltu2aingo The force of the
latter amounted to $500 men OF artillery
and cavalry. They fought for SIX hours
with skin ard energy, bur Welded at last to
the efforts OF or heroes, their cavalry being
completely routed and dispersed abandoning
the field Of battle, and leaving on It more
than 1920 dead bodies, among them that of
Marshal Abreu, 10 pieces Of artillery, all
their ammunition and baggage, with con
siderable number Of prisoners and arms.
The ,oss of the army ofthe Republic does
not exceed AGO men between killed and
wounded: among the former is to be regret
ted Col. bfand2en, who fell on the first charge
at the front of his regiment


"lt IS impossible at present 70 give a de
tail OF the events of the Goth: the General
in-Chief VIII transmit 1t very shortly. In the
meantime Lieutenant Coionel Aguirre, the
bearer OF this despatch, will inform your llx
cellencv OF them, and viii also present twc
standards which are the trophies pf the vic.
tory.


"Ihe advantages and consequences Of the
victory are immense. The General in
Chiet pursues the enemy to avail himself o
them; and, in the name of the army, he con
graduates both the Government and the Ma
tion. he General has the satisfaction e
assure the Minister of War, that every ind
vidnal OF the army has contributed in III,
most distinguished manner, to the happ,
result OF the battle of the Goth. The Under
signed hopes it will be communicated to Hi
Excellency the President, whom he salute
with his most distinguished respect.


"CARLOS DE ALVEAR.


"1o II. Is. the Minister of IHur."

full articles.headline: THE CANNING FAMILY.
full articles.article:
from ne CORK o0RNefn hefoTEeTJ


The family of Canning. from which the
present eminent and justly popular Prime
Minister springs, is of great antiquity.


The head the family was Roman Cath
oic gentleman. Francis Canning Esq, Of
Foxcote, in Warwick shire, the twelfth pos
SCISSOR of that estate, in lincal male descent
from Thomas Canning Esq. who, in the
reign of Henry VI, married Agnes, sole
heiress of lie Marshal, of Foxcotc, seated
there, from the time of Edward l.


The branch from which the premier de-
rives his origin was founded by George Can
ming, younger son of Richard Canning, of
Foxcote, who settled in Ireland. and obtain
ed grant Of the manor of Garvah. in the
county of Londonderry, from Queen Eliza
beth. From him descended Stratford Can
ning, Esq the fifth possessor of the Garvah
estate, who derived his Christian name from
the surname Of his mothcr's family, the
Stratfords, Earls of Aidborough; his eldest
son, George Canning, died in his fathers
lifetime leaving an only son, the Right Hon
orabie George Canning, who, though repre-
sentative OF tic elder branch OF the Garvah
family, was passed by in the will of his grand
father. who left the estate TO his second soi
Paul Canning, ESQ whose only son, George
Canning was created Baron GArvah in 1878.


The premier, however, succeeded to
small estate in the county of Kilkenny, OF
about $500 per annum, either by bequest,
or in consequence of the entail net being
broken. On this slender beginning he has
finally achieved his present proud pre- emi-
nence.


(Fr9m the London Eree Press.


Mr. Canning was born at Paddington.
near London, in 177l. His paterpal ances-
tors we're originally seated at Foxcote IN
Warwick shire, where branch OF the fali-
lily, We believe still remains,-Queen Eliza
beth conferred the manor OF Garvah, in the
county of Derry, in Ireland, ON a younger
son of the Foxcote family, who thcreupon
removed into the sister island, and up to tae
father Of the premier descendants Continued
Ia reside there Stratford Canning, Esq OF
Carsah, the grandfather had two sons
George and Paul, the elder of whom dl$-
pleasing his father by marrying dnwefiesSs
beauty, was cxied from the paternal roof
with an allowance of fsl50 year.
| Under these circumstances he cane w'tn
his lady to London, and determining to study
the law, entered himself of the Middle en- :
pie. lie died poor, on the lith Of .lprl''
l77l, . few davs ufter the birth Of his son
George, and was Inferred in the new hnrii
ground OF St. Marylebone, where his sorl''
with the following inscription, was placed ~
his widow -


Thy virtue and my wo, no words can tel,
! Therefore, a little while, my George, sareweili


For faith and love ike ours, Heaven has IN stofS
Its last best gift--to meet and part no more


His infant son, the subject Of this remor'
was placed with maternal uncle, "A F&s'ec.-
able wine merchant in the city, who discos
ering strong marks of genius, at very ear. ,,..
ly age, sent him to Eton, where he speeuNJ
distinguished himself, and in 1888, oeca'A-
one of the senior scholars.

tnrned to the Cdpital. The hrsr who re
turned was Mr.. Gorrti. appointed to VISIT
Cor,loya. A brief narration of the circum-
stances attendant Oh this mission may not
be found uninteresting.


The honorable Deputy arrived at Cordo-
va on the 9Th of January, and notihed his ar
rival to the Governor, Mr.. Bustos the
same evening. The following day he pre-
sentcd himself in person at his residence,
and delivered to him the Address of the
Congress, together with copy of the Con-
sttuton at the same time availng himself
of the opportunity to add a few remarks ON
the ardent desires OF the Congress for the re-
establishment Of internal order and peace by
means Of the Constitution, and expressing his
wishes to he permitted to hold a conference
with the Junto, for the purpose of ob9iating
any objections which might be urged against
its reception. The Governors answer was
chiefly confined to few remarks on scvera!
Of the laws Of the Congress, and evinced con
siderable resentment at the censures which
had been passed on him in some ct the pc
riodical papers OF Bucno, Ayres; and nc rep
robatcd the conduct of Bedoya, the parti-
zan Chief OF the General Governmentl in
advancing to Santiago. The deputy, in his





these occurrences, and to remove the re-
sponsibllities from the Congress. which dis
claimed any participation in them. On the
| 10th, the Governor directed note to him,
stating that the Junto was not in session, but
that standing committee of that body was
| fully authorised TO determine Oh all matters
pertaining to the legislative functions during
the recess After having overcome yari-
ETY. OF difficulties and impediments, which a
/ rose to prevent the full and formal discus
| sion OF the subject. and which an unlucky
understanding had nearly cut off the hope OF
realizing, On the 9TH at night the Commit
tee asScmblca tohcar the exposition which
the deputy had to offer in support OF the
! Constitution. / he conferences were held
! Tor two lights only, during which the Com
mittce proposed "a number of objections, and
4 heard the replies OF the deputy, who most
ably defended the conduct and principles Of
the Constituent Congress, though without
producing any bcne fetal effect The night
subsequent to the last conference, the Com


mittcc sat alone, to deliberate on the conduct


10 be observed relative TO the Constitution


and came to The resolution ITO refuse to cx
anime IL" stating that "the province had


separated from the Mon, aud therefore NO
: comprehended IN the fundamental law whcl


provides that tic Constitution shall be sub


iniltcd to The appreciation Of each province.
lor this reason, they ordered ''the Constitu


tion sanctioned by he Congress res!tlcnt il
Bucnos Ayres, to be returned o The deputy
together with his Credentials" and, to Gloss


the whole, added q percEptary command t.
leave the city in f3 hours III consequence,
q these proceedings, the deputy had 10 9th
cr alternative than an implicit compliance
with these ipiInction9, his only satistactio,


beng tic Crntcl6'isuess IS OF having faithful,
and honourtUIy discharged ali inportan
, trust


:! he Editor Of the Argentine News, re


marks -. ! he impression which the perus,
Of the document leaves OIL the mind, is lit


tie favourable IL t1e character Of the prov
. inct, OF It's authorities Their oppositio
has dcgcnerated from principled resist


,.nce, into the pervcrse and unjusti6ahe ob
= stnacy oi party spirit, which knows no me
y dinm between unlimited submission to il
CLAIMS, and the absolute rejection Of all prop


0sitons tending to concijatc the larring in
- tertsta ot the community. The suppose


invasion of right, by the laws of capitalZa
tion, Sic. has br,E foniullnAcd with the pei


sonal cenSurcs ofperiolicAl jaurnalS, 70 Wine


the Congress u Hot prvy. he feelings {
: individuals have been pfcterI cd to the intci


ests OF the public ne rcscntments and Il


imositIts oI Il few have been made the unha


lowed touchstone Of political principlce, an
q to crafty them have been sacrificed the II
e ternal peace, with the credit and charactt


OF the nation.

full articles.headline: NEW HARMONY.
full articles.article:
The last New Harmony Gazette contains
the address of Robert Owen, the proprietor
of that community, previous to his leaving
.he place for Europe. He enumerates the
difficulties he has experienced in carrying
his project into effect, and the causes Of his
failure. lie has sold a part, and leased out
the remainder of his property at New Har-
mony to communities on a small scale, and
thinks that on this plan his hopes Of success
will in some measure be realized. He re-
commends to those he leaves behind him, in
dustry, economy, perseverance and kindness,
to one another, and hopes to meet them a.
gain under more favorable auspices.

still more i.fur;1ted to find tie yctim had
escaped. he turned towards the horseman;
the latter opposed him with his pike, wh'cn
he plunged into his neck. but the ahi.na'
was too much eXasperated to be diverted by
this He threw up his head, Knocked away
the spear, dashed at the horse, plunged his
horns into him mp to the head, and tossed
him and the rider over his back. Down
came horse and horseman---thc latter under
the former. The horse making one effort,
sprung upon his feet, and the man was able
hastily to crawl oct of one the apertures.--
The matatlors diverted the attention OF the
bull to the other side. The dying horse
was forced through the gate where he hau
entercd-thc man was not seriously injured.
The applause Of the multitude tor TINS act
of the bull was still louder than the former,
magled at the same time with hisseS at the
driven for his overthrow. he death-note
Of the bull was now sounded, and the Wata-
dor stepped in front of him. The bull tiew
at him, and the sword was so deXterously
directed that it entered nearly To the hht,
and passed through the heart OF the animal
He gave one violent shake OF the hcad,
threw the sword from his body, caught the
robe Of the matador on his horns, shook 1t IN
the ain in triumph, and coming to the cen





down dead Another gate was now thrown
open, and three horses aud three negroes en-
tered at full speed. A rope was in an in
slant fastened round the horns OF the ami
nal, and IN the space of minute he was
drawn from the hM-Q Another horse was
procured in the place Of the one Killed, and
another bull entered the inn; after fighting
bravely, he was killed and disposed 0. in the
same manner.


The fourth ball now appeared. lie was
remarkably lean, and apparently weak.
Ihe picador attempted tn plunge the ban
lerllas in his neck, but he gave Sudden
| leap and reached the circle unhurt lhere
he stood ready for contest, when one Of the
picadors as it not satisfied that he had es-
caped the banderilas at the gate, ran and
dcxteronsly plunged them into his neck. -.
\ The bull attempted 10 receive him, but his
/ horn caught bv only a part OF the dress OF
4 the picador; the cliea OF the multitude agaln
! rent the air This experiment vas several
times successfully repeated The fifth uui


entered, and after paving where the bloot
of thr previous oucs had tiown and making
the noise ot lamentatiVn which instlrc


prompts, utterly refused to be provoked t


fght Cries Of "CoWard, turn him out, turn
Y MIN out /" followed, aud he was withdrawn n


The other bulls which entered acted th'


same scene over, and a description Of Cours,


is unnecessary. There were, think, sev


en- Killed aud two withdrawn. nine in all.


With respect to the classes Of people VIII


attend here, il r,ay be remarked, that 1.


the head stands the Lieutenant Governo
= uf the island. Several boxes are appropri
ated to The upper order of females, thonsl
it is considered much less respectable thai
: formerly to be seen there. The Captain
General has recently issued orders 70 prc
! veut BOYS from acting as picadors. becaus
!. three were killed few DAYS ptt.uHisly I
! the fight which | have described cir
{ cumstancc which exhibits the feelings ~
cited oy such scenes when attended hy Oh
] country women, lately occurred. After re
I pcatcd solicitations, an American lady wa
I induced to enter the fh420 DE- foros. A
: Tie FIRST appearance Of thc bull, the pluug
y ng Of the barbcd banderlas. and the eXpll
: s'on. she tainted and was carried "ut t.--Suc
q delicacy ought always to characterize on
i females

College Froiics.--At Bowdon College. in
Name, the students lately showed themselves
somewhat refractory to the discipline of the
place One ct their number was suspended
eight or ten days for some offence, and his
CLASS hnding the sentence not to agre- with
their views OF the justice of the case, resolv-
cd 70 40 something really worthy of punish

lnglancing over the files of Buenos Ayrcs
papers alluded to in our last, we have found
few interesting articles relating to that
portion OF our continent, which we give be-
low.


Another revolutionary movement took
place at Santiago, in Chill, short time since.
in an attempt of the military, headed by
that restless and dangerous man CAMPING,
to dissolve the sitting Of the Sovereign Con
gress and to abolish the Eatanco. For this
purpose the troops were formed in front of
the Congress Hall, and some muskets were
discharged, but without effect, and the Con
gress merely suspended its sitting. in the
meanwhile, CAMPING took possession OF the
Government House, imprisoned the Secreta-
ry of Foreign Relations and the Chief Of the
E.stanco, and proclaimed himself President
of the Republic. Negotiations then COM
mcncca between him and the Congress, but
before coming to any conclusion, the troops
deserted him, and he and his principal ad-
herents were thrown into prison. 1t is thus
that the rcpose of Chill is continually dis
turbed by the different factions that alter
nately distract her Councils, and hold in
check any considerable improvement in her
institutions.


he deputies who were sent by the gov
ernment OF Buenos Ayres to present the
constitution to the dissident provinces, have


been unsuccessful in their mission; and
/ with the exception OF one or two, had re.

A letter has been received from Captain
Worrcl. of the Tontine, the first vessel des.
patched from Philadelphia with provisions
for the Greeks, announcing his safe arrival
at Gibraltar on the 21st of April, after pas
sage OF "a days. lie says, II am sorry to
say there are none of our squadron here at
present, all being up the Mediterranean; we
are, therefore, unable to obtain any informa-
ton from that quarter. Should we be so
fortunate as to meet either of them, it is the
general impression that they will give US
convoy" Capt. w. proceeded on his voy-
| age Oh the esd.

We understand that thc Corporation of
this Borough have purchased the Mill ad-
Joining the Brandywinc bridge, Of Mr.. John
Cummins, and in the course of the ensuing
Summer it viii be used to raise the water
from the Brandywine Greek for tie use Of
this town.


Our citizens have long felt the want Of
a suiicIency Of water to answer ordinary
purposes, and should fire at any time have
occurred, the destruction of properly would
have been very great, The water will be
raised to the basin already constructed, and
distributed through iron pipes.

The Postmaster General Of the United
States, left Washington on Friday. on Wis
it to his domcile in the State of Ohio, being
the first visit he has made thither since his
appointment TO office. four or five years ago.
He is expected to be absent for five or six
weeks.

flSer.

CUEA IN 1897.
full articles.article:
OF Otner UationS, nave lutTouuNeu ii''o e"N'


colonies the habits and manners OF the moth


er country. Their attachment to bull-hght-
ing has been proverbal for many years.


In Cuba the Creoles have added great


love Of cock fighting. have seen dozen


gentlemen, on buord Spanish steamboat.


each accompanied with a game cock. and


servant to attend him. The bull night Is,


however, considered the most magnificent


display, both from the number OF pcrsonag-


cs who attend, the skill of the combatants,
and the power OF the enemy.


Within eight rods of the walls o! the Ha-
vana, and near the most southern ot the hve
gates, is erected a large wooden ampltheatre
with two rows Of boxes. one above the oth~
er, on the ordinary plan OF circus, except
ing that il is much larger, and has no PIT. IL
is called Plaza Ge 1oreS--litcraly "bnli
place" Here every four days, the mhab,t-
! ants Of the Havana have an opportunity OF


witnessing the sport Of Span'ards. Foreign
ers who visit either Spain or her colonies,
usually go from curiosity or ether motives,
/ oRcc : and this is quite enough. ATTENDED,


one.
/ Notice had been given by the superintend-


ent, that, ever anxious to CRAFTY the iperai


and enlightened public OF Havana, NO pans
| had been spared To train the bulls properly,


to make them fierce, and to render the eX-
hibition highly superior. 1t commenced at


O'Clock, p. NJ. The price OF entrance was
half "A dollar on the shady side, and twenty
FIVE cents where the spectators were expos


cd to the sun; twenty-five cents additional


where a special seat was furnished


At the time we entered the mass of peo-


pie had assemblies; and in being few min


utes past the hour, the shouts of the mob


were loud for the appearance of the bull
There were, as far AS we could judge, about
5000 persons present few minutes more


elapsed, aud the cries Of the spectators, for


bull, again rent the air. On one side Of .Oe


arena gate was thrown open. ana two men


on horseback entered: one clothed IN black,


and tNe other IN SILK They wore also mi.


itarv cauS. and were armed with long smooth


poles (picas) al the end Of which WAS q snall
pike, about an inch III lcnglh. lhcv wrfc
decorated with great variety ot rih1ohs OF


different colours, ticd in bows At their SAou!
! ders, knees, breasts, and arms. lheN wore
, stout. heavy, leathcrn boots. which reaeh"d
a nearly to their thighs The horses and their
/ accoutremrnts were also adorned with rib-
/ bons Handkcrchiets were passed round
. their heads, between their trelock ana thc
T. ewes in order to blind them IN tho contest
5 The riders wore long sharp spurs. These
+ are called Gic0Gorea Next appeared toll
e others, OH foot, clothed in yellow scarlet
4 black, and green satin, with similar decora
3 lions of ribbons; but without Caps. Then
!, hair was fastened in queue behind, ant
: they wore no boots, but breeches, witt
4 white silk stockings and the li6htest pumps
y Each in his hand bore piece of silk, abou
= halt ward wide, and two yards long, O
e the same color as his dress. The mob hail
~. xutth 1Hf
u shout; and the sound of the trumpet was th
= = signal for the coming Of the bull On tn
, opposite side from where the horses had GU
a tered, a gate was thrown open, and MAJ
20 stood over the top Of it with two barbcd az
If rows (called dQuderUos) which displayed
h variety of paper decorations. Ihe anime
r. appeared AZ the gate; the man plunged th
r- bande riius into his back; and ALI the pape
5; decorations in a moment exploded. In
~ butt, with sudden bound and apparent!
a with his back all or fire, lcaped 10 the centl
us Of the circle Panied by the arrows in hi
40 neck, he stopped il IL moment, snuiied tn
to air, gaaed at the spectators, and shook HI
to head in defiance. The matadorcs appeare
ne before him, aud threw their robes. Fl
ny caught the colors they displayed, llcw ;
Y them With the rapidly Of lightning, and the
nc left the lng in a moment, through small az


=, ertures situated about eight feet apart, ruuN
- the circle. He then turned at the horse an
:. rider. The pike was thurst into his nee


by the horsrman. the spurs applied, aud tor
h. moment, by the sting, the attention OF Il
III, bull was diverted The rnatadores appea
M. cd at several points again, and the seer
mi was repeated: they coming and disappea
alf ing with the same rapidlty as before. III
nd shouts Of the crowd continued as either pa
Il ty was successful; and the ladies waved the
he handkerchieis to encourage the men to
IN valiantly. At length tine trumpet sound'
IRE signal tor the death OF the bull, and OF
40 of the matadores stepped in front Of hi
rs, with sword of three and half feet
ed length, and waved his scarlet silk garme
es, as challenge. The bull, however, was
IN much exhausted, that he declined the cor
ch bat; and the matadnr made signal to Il
ue governor of the hght with bis sword. IT
ch en- was answered by another flourish of t
tui trumpet; and the gate through which c
= ball had entered was opened. Two SIN
-, bulls, which are kept for guides, came
NV nn and then the three were driven out toget
n. er.


osi. The noise of the crowd ceased tor m
af- mcnt, but soon they shouted foi another br
ice The gate was thrown open as before. t
ep, arrows were plunged into the neck of t
5ut- animal, the explosion followed, and he pa
.he ed round the circle in moment. Near {
ncr centre Of ring was a post, 10 which me
ap- key was tied. The bull flew az the monk,


thp :, n, ,,pOn tho tor, of +he r.o

state of distraction, and to render the prosPee'
widely unlike those scenes OF quietude, wnch
soothe and soften the mind, and bid It reject
with composure. Here we were above all living
beings. the sole inhabitants ofa region far above
the lofty fight Of the eagle, where the foot OF
the chamois never ventures, and where man mas
seldom BEEN


We stood amidst the frowns Of savage Nature,
almost insensble to every object beneath' ana
silently contemplating the coudIess heaSe"s'
pure and bright as the I'm, ied wastes OF s,oW
around and beneath. liere all worldly passions
cease; mans thoughts occupy themselves III
more worthy train of reflection; he fofge's inc
Injustice of his enemies ms sou' raises 'seii 70
heaven. as its nearest point, and reioices to feel
it..lf nearer the abode of truth. "Le vra nous
Went du ciel, l'erreur Went dc la terre." When
we meet we viii enlarge upon the subject, IN ihe
mean time will briefly state our mode OF descent
an operation very different from that pursued in
ascending.
On reaching the edge of the decHyity which
led to the Petlts Mulets, Contet told me that
would not be safe to walk down, and on inquiry
itound the usual practice was to seat yol.rsel on
the ice between two guides, and thus slie GOWN
IN few minutes the distance which had cost us
an hour and half to ascend lsubmiited to the
plan suggested to me; and though the operation
1 somewhat hazardous, the agility OF the guides
in regulating the velocity by means OF thelr
poles, seems to remove all danger. In descend
ing this first slope by this new method, cast
my ewes once or twice over the precipice TO our
right hand, ana had Just one moment to THINK,
that if by an Inflated turn, VIC had directed our
course that way, it appeared that We shoulI
most unexpectedly have paid visit to the good
monks Of St. Bernard. When ut Les Pet'ts NiIl-
lets, begged Coutet to stop q few minutes tha'
l might once more look up at the hoary summit
Of Mont Blanc; and having rested = short time,
and gathered few fragments OF granite from
sls, the highest bare point, we continued our
line of march.

On Monday last, in New-York, four bows
between the ages of nine and twelve years
were committed to Biidewell, on charge
of robbing Sabbath School. For the last
two months, they had been in the habit OF
watching opportunities during the absenc.
OF the sections OF two churches. in the vicin.
'ty of Bowery and Spring street, to pocke
the collections taken up during service.
